title: 110_s738
content: The "Small Business International Trade Enhancements Act of 2007" includes a provision for the appointment of a Small Business Administration Associate Administrator for International Trade. The Small Business International Trade Enhancements Act of 2007 establishes the Associate Administrator for International Trade within the Small Business Administration. This individual will be responsible for the Office of International Trade and discharge international trade responsibilities. The Small Business Act is amended to ensure that the Associate Administrator for International Trade has the resources and authority to carry out international trade responsibilities effectively. The Small Business Act is amended to appoint an Associate Administrator for International Trade, enhancing resources and authority for carrying out international trade responsibilities effectively. The Small Business Act is amended to create the Office of International Trade, replacing Section 22 with enhanced resources and authority for international trade responsibilities. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of International Trade, enhancing resources and authority for international trade responsibilities. The Office will maintain a trade distribution network through regional and local offices, small business development centers, women's business centers, and export centers for trade promotion and finance. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of International Trade, which focuses on trade promotion, finance, adjustment, remedy assistance, and data collection. The Office sets annual goals to enhance exporting capabilities, facilitate technology transfers, and improve programs for small businesses to compete globally. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of International Trade, which aims to enhance small businesses' access to capital, disseminate information on programs, and represent their interests in trade negotiations. The Office identifies subsectors with export potential and areas of demand in foreign markets. The Office of International Trade enhances small businesses' access to capital, disseminates information on programs, and represents their interests in trade negotiations by identifying areas of demand in foreign markets and prescreening foreign buyers for commercial and credit purposes. In subsection (d), the development specialist is required to participate in an annual training program focusing on small business exporting needs and jointly develop training programs with relevant agencies. In subsection (d), the Office shall designate a trade financial specialist to accomplish the goal of working in cooperation with relevant Federal agencies and implementing export financing programs. The Office designates a trade financial specialist to oversee international loan programs, assist with trade finance issues, and report annually on progress and activities. During 2006-2009, the Administrator must maintain a certain number of employees at Export Assistance Centers, with priority given to placing Administration employees at these centers. The Administrator strategically assigns employees to Export Assistance Centers based on exporter needs and works with other agencies to establish annual goals for the centers. An individual is designated for oversight. The Office designates an individual to oversee activities conducted by Administration employees at Export Centers. SEC. 4. INTERNATIONAL TRADE LOANS. Section 7(a)(3)(B) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the loan amount to $2,750,000. Section 7(a)(16)(A) is also amended to include providing working capital as a loan option. Section 7(a)(16)(B) of the Small Business Act is amended to allow loans to be secured by a second lien position on property or equipment financed by the loan. This provides adequate assurance of payment according to the Administrator. Refinancing under the Small Business Act is amended to include debt qualifying for refinancing under other provisions of the subsection.
